Title: EP. REVIEW: Arifureta - From Commonplace to World's Strongest Season 2 [1/4] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: Goto page 1, 2, 3, 4  Next Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        FilthyCasual    Joined: 01 Jun 2015 		    Posts: 1684       Posted: Thu Jan 20, 2022 8:32 pm            Enjoyable popcorn with entertaining interactions and reasonably drawn, if not particularly dynamic, combat.     I'm glad to have Arifureta back looking better than ever.      Back to top                  Yttrbio   Subscriber   Joined: 09 Jun 2011 		    Posts: 3535       Posted: Thu Jan 20, 2022 8:44 pm            I don't know if there's a version of these fights that's engaging, but even the characters seem bored with the idea. I'm generally pretty "done" with anime fighting as it is, but this show's feels especially perfunctory. No passion, no stakes, no creativity. They really brought out the level of excitement "I guess I have to go farm 100 lava snakes at Hot Mountain for this quest" or "I wonder what it looks like when I use this new weapon" triggers when you encounter it in an MMO. Digging a hole came across as more interesting.   I stick around for the slightly-pointy banter, though, and hey, maybe what I assume is some kind of Angel Beam heralds something a bit more gripping.      Back to top                  TarsTarkas    Joined: 20 Dec 2007 		    Posts: 5255 		    Location: Virginia, United States 		        Posted: Fri Jan 21, 2022 3:46 am            As a fan of the franchise, the anime will still be a must watch for me, no matter how bad it could get.   My main concern is how the second season will handle the content, that was skipped over in the first season.  Since the first season was nothing more than a travelogue.   spoiler[They glossed over Verbergen and skipped the encounters with the Hoelscher Empire.]  It would be a shame if they excised these from the anime, since spoiler[ the blood bath in the Empire was a glorious moment in the light novel]      Back to top                  Cryten    Joined: 19 Jan 2019 		    Posts: 542       Posted: Fri Jan 21, 2022 6:13 am            Well I cant get as much fun dunking on the series anymore, since its actually competent now even if it doesnt stand out. Actually from the preview I thought it might be a bunch of stills again but we are normally getting at least a few frames of swinging a weapon animation now. Its a plus!   Though without it being atrocious it feels a bit more average now. Perhaps that is because we have had a few more of the chuni style wacky leads in the last 2 years. Like Kemono Michi, Combatants will be dispatched and quite a few I rule out as close to chuni but not overtly such as Reincarnated as a Spider and Fruit of Evolution.   For ep 2, I dont believe for a single second that Hajime could be threatened. More likely the old staple of getting his reward stolen to try and create a credible threat. Though I think the series would more likely go for just overwhelming a foe who thinks he's got him on the hop.      Back to top                  borisdrakoni    Joined: 27 Apr 2019 		    Posts: 23       Posted: Fri Jan 21, 2022 10:17 am              TarsTarkas wrote:    As a fan of the franchise, the anime will still be a must watch for me, no matter how bad it could get.   My main concern is how the second season will handle the content, that was skipped over in the first season.  Since the first season was nothing more than a travelogue.   spoiler[They glossed over Verbergen and skipped the encounters with the Hoelscher Empire.]  It would be a shame if they excised these from the anime, since spoiler[ the blood bath in the Empire was a glorious moment in the light novel]      There's always the possibility that this season won't get to the part in the story where the skipped content from season 1 becomes relevant.   The pacing so far has been fairly steady, and with only 12 aired episodes listed volume 6 would probably be a better stopping point.  As far as the spoiler[Empire] is concerned, I wouldn't be too surprised if at least spoiler[Gahard] was retroactively introduced here in the next couple of episodes when the story checks in on the Hero party side since spoiler[they don't have much to do for awhile].   So far, I've been enjoying the second season.  Though far from top tier, the animation quality is noticeably improved, and the writing doesn't seem to be in as big of a hurry as season 1 to speed run through the content.  The new opening and ending themes are quite good, and Ryou Takahashi's work on the bgms is as on point as always.  Of course, the return of the weekly Twitter shorts are also a welcome injection of comedy into the story.  We'll have to see where things go, but from the first two episodes at least there's plenty of room for some cautious optimism.      Back to top                  sadoldguy    Joined: 01 Aug 2009 		    Posts: 38       Posted: Fri Jan 21, 2022 11:07 am            "Make out" session, right.  I tolerate the light novel and manga enough but never watched the first season, so my impression is that they upped the edgelord aspects but toned down the sex and violence.      Back to top                  Picky33    Joined: 09 Jul 2021 		    Posts: 215       Posted: Fri Jan 21, 2022 4:34 pm            After how long it's been since the first season i was surprised to get another. I really enjoyed the first season. my only worry with the first episode is they haven't done any explaining so anyone who never read the LN, Manga, Watched the first season won't have any good understandings of what's going on.    Looking at the first episode without any context it's hard to follow along. Hopefully that improves in subsequent episodes (only watched the first so far).      Back to top                  TarsTarkas    Joined: 20 Dec 2007 		    Posts: 5255 		    Location: Virginia, United States 		        Posted: Tue Jan 25, 2022 1:42 am            I watched the first two episodes, so this definitely is a step up from the first season.  Wished that the OP was a bit more exciting, but at least this OP was slightly better than the first season's horrible OP.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3769       Posted: Sun Jan 30, 2022 12:17 am            Even if it was because he got the drop on him, it's nice to see an antagonist that's actually giving Hajime some trouble for once.    It was nice to see some Tio spotlight and to see her proclaim her love for Hajime. I wonder if Shea will get a spotlight episode this season.    Seems like there's intrigue back with Hajime's old classmates...I almost forgot about the conspiracy going on. Dude really just doesn't get how little Hajime cares about the attempted murder or Kaori going along with him, but now he's basically asking for Hajime to kill him.   Shizuku's one weakness...cats. Remia's hair looks darker in the LN.   On another note though, at this point in season 2. Remia is only pretending to like Hajime as so not to hurt Myuu's feelings. Title: EP. REVIEW: Arifureta - From Commonplace to World's Strongest Season 2 [1/4] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: I don't know if there's a version of these fights that's engaging, but even the characters seem bored with the idea. I'm generally pretty "done" with anime fighting as it is, but this show's feels especially perfunctory. No passion, no stakes, no creativity. They really brought out the level of excitement "I guess I have to go farm 100 lava snakes at Hot Mountain for this quest" or "I wonder what it looks like when I use this new weapon" triggers when you encounter it in an MMO. Digging a hole came across as more interesting.   I stick around for the slightly-pointy banter, though, and hey, maybe what I assume is some kind of Angel Beam heralds something a bit more gripping.

Title: EP. REVIEW: Arifureta - From Commonplace to World's Strongest Season 2 [1/4] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: As a fan of the franchise, the anime will still be a must watch for me, no matter how bad it could get.   My main concern is how the second season will handle the content, that was skipped over in the first season.  Since the first season was nothing more than a travelogue.   spoiler[They glossed over Verbergen and skipped the encounters with the Hoelscher Empire.]  It would be a shame if they excised these from the anime, since spoiler[ the blood bath in the Empire was a glorious moment in the light novel]

Title: EP. REVIEW: Arifureta - From Commonplace to World's Strongest Season 2 [1/4] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: TarsTarkas wrote:    As a fan of the franchise, the anime will still be a must watch for me, no matter how bad it could get.   My main concern is how the second season will handle the content, that was skipped over in the first season.  Since the first season was nothing more than a travelogue.   spoiler[They glossed over Verbergen and skipped the encounters with the Hoelscher Empire.]  It would be a shame if they excised these from the anime, since spoiler[ the blood bath in the Empire was a glorious moment in the light novel]      There's always the possibility that this season won't get to the part in the story where the skipped content from season 1 becomes relevant.   The pacing so far has been fairly steady, and with only 12 aired episodes listed volume 6 would probably be a better stopping point.  As far as the spoiler[Empire] is concerned, I wouldn't be too surprised if at least spoiler[Gahard] was retroactively introduced here in the next couple of episodes when the story checks in on the Hero party side since spoiler[they don't have much to do for awhile].   So far, I've been enjoying the second season.  Though far from top tier, the animation quality is noticeably improved, and the writing doesn't seem to be in as big of a hurry as season 1 to speed run through the content.  The new opening and ending themes are quite good, and Ryou Takahashi's work on the bgms is as on point as always.  Of course, the return of the weekly Twitter shorts are also a welcome injection of comedy into the story.  We'll have to see where things go, but from the first two episodes at least there's plenty of room for some cautious optimism.

Title: EP. REVIEW: Arifureta - From Commonplace to World's Strongest Season 2 [1/4] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: I love Yue just casually sitting on Hajime's crotch and undressing so she and Hajime could have sub sex. That's couple goals.    Poor Shea gives up her blood and then has to catch Hajime and Yue at the end of their lovemaking. Throw her a bone, Hajime!   I love how Kaori finally gets her moment with Hajime only for Tio to interrupt it and shove Hajime into her boobs.   Sayaka Ohara playing a hot anime mom. It's almost becoming her thing as much as it is Kikuko Inoue's. What's funny is I was reminded on reddit that she had already played Shea's mom in a flashback, which implies that either they forgot about it and just cast her as another mom or Sayaka Ohara is going to play every characters' mom.    Really curious where the intrigue in the kingdom is going and if it'll intersect with Hajime's story at all this season...and now Shizuku knows Hajime did something to Ai-chan.

The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Thermae Romae Novae   Apr  1st 2022                   How would you rate episode 1 of Thermae Romae Novae (ONA) ?                     Community score: 3.0              What is this?   In Hadrian Rome, Lucius was a Roman architect whose designs often got rejected by builders. To cheer him up a friend of his invited him to relax at a thermae (public bath). Inside the bath Lucius was accidentally trapped in an underwater hole by suction; when he finally managed to emerge on the surface he found himself in a very different bath: in 20th century Japan.    Thermae Romae Novae is based on Mari Yamazaki's manga and is currently streaming on Netflix.      How was the first episode?    James Beckett  Rating:                One of the things that comes with having major ADHD is learning how to manage constantly shifting hyperfixations, which is to say that I can totally understand how something like Thermae Romae Novae could come into existence. I've spent a frankly embarrassing amount of hours obsessing over kaiju movies, tokusatsu shows, Gunpla models, and The Muppets (and that's just the stuff I've gotten into over the last five years or so), so I'm not all surprised to learn that there exists at least one person in the world whose love for ancient history, architecture, and public bathhouses intersected with such ferocity that an entire multi-media franchise was born.    Here's my main issue with Thermae Romae Novae: While I'm certainly always down to dig into some history and culture lessons, I myself don't particularly care about architecture, and I've never even stepped foot inside of a public bathhouse. Our main character, Lucius, has precisely two personality traits: He freaking loves architecture, and his dream in life is to—and I quote—“Build bathhouses that make everyone smile!” Even when you include the series' novel time-travel angle (which doesn't really impact the first episode of the show at all), the core of Thermae Romae Novae's appeal lies in its unapologetic obsession with bathhouse cultures past and present.    What that means is that, outside of the very specific niche appeal of the bathhouses themselves, I'm not finding much else to latch onto with this story. The historical drama isn't well-written enough to hold up on its own, and there's not much humor to be found outside of that. In short, while the material here is perfectly fine for an educational documentary, I'm not sure it makes for the kind of anime that I want to sit down and watch on a regular basis.    Heck, the anime actually comes with live-action documentary segments that close out its episodes, and I find those much more compelling than the rest of the show that they're attached to. The segments that follow author Mari Yamazaki's quest to “rediscover Japanese bathhouse culture” are genuinely interesting and feature some lovely footage of real-world bathhouse settings, and the anime's relatively drab and uninspired visuals simply don't hold up in comparison. It doesn't help that, in all of the scenes set inside the thermae themselves (of which there are many), the show slaps this hideous and cheap looking steam filter on top of the screen.    I've heard that Thermae Romae has a sizeable fan-base, so it's quite possible that future episodes of the show would give me more of a reason to stick around and get invested in the bathhouse mania of it all. As it stands, though, I don't think Thermae Romae Novae is for me; at the very least, if I ever do come back to the show, I can easily imagine skipping all of the anime parts to get to the documentary bits. That's apparently where the real bathhouse action is at.        Caitlin Moore  Rating:               The manga of Thermae Romae is a critically-acclaimed award winner. The first anime adaptation was a low-budget short that developed a cult following for its quirky humor. The new series that just premiered on Netflix, Thermae Romae Novae, has a TV run's worth of full-length episodes, complete with attempts at pathos and backstory, and has the same director as the critically-panned Africa Salaryman. It is also boring.    For a series with a concept as weird as “Roman architect time travels through a portal in a bath for inspiration,” you really don't need to put a lot of effort into building up character motivation. Yet for some reason, they felt the need to give Lucius a reason to really love baths and a tragic childhood involving a dead father and bullies. Can't he just be a dude who loves soaking in hot water and designing new ways to do it? The first episode has no jokes and just feels long, drawn-out, and pointless.    Yet somehow, that's not the most baffling decision the anime staff made. You see, the people in togas and marble buildings with columns aren't enough to make us realize this shit all happened a long time ago. We couldn't possibly manage to figure that out on our own. The distant past was all sepia-toned, right? They didn't invent bright colors until the '50s! Everything up until then was muddy and dim. Unfortunately, the half-assed color design, along with the pen-and-ink style shading, makes it look like everything has been rubbed with dirt. In a series about bathing and cleanliness. It's silly.    Maybe Thermae Romae Novae picks up after this. I hear it has Kenjiro Tsuda yelling in Latin, so that's something.       Richard Eisenbeis  Rating:                It's funny, Thermae Romae is so mainstream here in Japan that despite never having read a page of the manga nor having seen the live-action film, I already knew the basic setup through cultural osmosis alone—which is why watching this threw me for a bit of a loop. What I was expecting was a time-traveling Roman being awed by some facet of Japanese hot spring culture over and over again. And while that may be what the series turns into, this first episode was most certainly not.    Rather, this episode gives us the backstory for our series' protagonist Lucius, showing why he became a bathhouse architect and where his philosophy on bathing came from. But more than that, this episode is about how blue-collar workers find importance and pride in their daily toil. For a mason, it's knowing that their work will record the past and inspire the future. For Lucius' father and grandfather, it's about creating a place where people can be purged of stress and be ready to face a new day. In other words, they may be cogs in Roman society, but they know that they are vital to its functioning.    It makes for a solid setup to the series, even if it's ultimately not representative of the rest of the show. It's just a shame that the animation doesn't really hold up. In wide shots there is a noticeable drop in detail and in scenes with any kind of quick movement, it looks choppy to say the least. And the live-action ending with the author of the manga is pretty much Japanese TV in a nutshell—i.e., a person traveling around Japan talking about how cool some aspect of Japanese culture (usually food) really is.    All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More          ⬈ ⬋ - +                            feature          74 comments       The Spring 2022 Preview Guide   Apr  4, 01:29 74 comments                 anime    The thrilling conclusion of Magia Record is live! The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Thermae Romae Novae   Apr  1st 2022                   How would you rate episode 1 of Thermae Romae Novae (ONA) ?                     Community score: 3.0              What is this?   In Hadrian Rome, Lucius was a Roman architect whose designs often got rejected by builders. To cheer him up a friend of his invited him to relax at a thermae (public bath). Inside the bath Lucius was accidentally trapped in an underwater hole by suction; when he finally managed to emerge on the surface he found himself in a very different bath: in 20th century Japan.    Thermae Romae Novae is based on Mari Yamazaki's manga and is currently streaming on Netflix.      How was the first episode?    James Beckett  Rating:                One of the things that comes with having major ADHD is learning how to manage constantly shifting hyperfixations, which is to say that I can totally understand how something like Thermae Romae Novae could come into existence. I've spent a frankly embarrassing amount of hours obsessing over kaiju movies, tokusatsu shows, Gunpla models, and The Muppets (and that's just the stuff I've gotten into over the last five years or so), so I'm not all surprised to learn that there exists at least one person in the world whose love for ancient history, architecture, and public bathhouses intersected with such ferocity that an entire multi-media franchise was born.    Here's my main issue with Thermae Romae Novae: While I'm certainly always down to dig into some history and culture lessons, I myself don't particularly care about architecture, and I've never even stepped foot inside of a public bathhouse. Our main character, Lucius, has precisely two personality traits: He freaking loves architecture, and his dream in life is to—and I quote—“Build bathhouses that make everyone smile!” Even when you include the series' novel time-travel angle (which doesn't really impact the first episode of the show at all), the core of Thermae Romae Novae's appeal lies in its unapologetic obsession with bathhouse cultures past and present.    What that means is that, outside of the very specific niche appeal of the bathhouses themselves, I'm not finding much else to latch onto with this story. The historical drama isn't well-written enough to hold up on its own, and there's not much humor to be found outside of that. In short, while the material here is perfectly fine for an educational documentary, I'm not sure it makes for the kind of anime that I want to sit down and watch on a regular basis.    Heck, the anime actually comes with live-action documentary segments that close out its episodes, and I find those much more compelling than the rest of the show that they're attached to. The segments that follow author Mari Yamazaki's quest to “rediscover Japanese bathhouse culture” are genuinely interesting and feature some lovely footage of real-world bathhouse settings, and the anime's relatively drab and uninspired visuals simply don't hold up in comparison. It doesn't help that, in all of the scenes set inside the thermae themselves (of which there are many), the show slaps this hideous and cheap looking steam filter on top of the screen.    I've heard that Thermae Romae has a sizeable fan-base, so it's quite possible that future episodes of the show would give me more of a reason to stick around and get invested in the bathhouse mania of it all. As it stands, though, I don't think Thermae Romae Novae is for me; at the very least, if I ever do come back to the show, I can easily imagine skipping all of the anime parts to get to the documentary bits. That's apparently where the real bathhouse action is at.        Caitlin Moore  Rating:               The manga of Thermae Romae is a critically-acclaimed award winner. The first anime adaptation was a low-budget short that developed a cult following for its quirky humor. The new series that just premiered on Netflix, Thermae Romae Novae, has a TV run's worth of full-length episodes, complete with attempts at pathos and backstory, and has the same director as the critically-panned Africa Salaryman. It is also boring.    For a series with a concept as weird as “Roman architect time travels through a portal in a bath for inspiration,” you really don't need to put a lot of effort into building up character motivation. Yet for some reason, they felt the need to give Lucius a reason to really love baths and a tragic childhood involving a dead father and bullies. Can't he just be a dude who loves soaking in hot water and designing new ways to do it? The first episode has no jokes and just feels long, drawn-out, and pointless.    Yet somehow, that's not the most baffling decision the anime staff made. You see, the people in togas and marble buildings with columns aren't enough to make us realize this shit all happened a long time ago. We couldn't possibly manage to figure that out on our own. The distant past was all sepia-toned, right? They didn't invent bright colors until the '50s! Everything up until then was muddy and dim. Unfortunately, the half-assed color design, along with the pen-and-ink style shading, makes it look like everything has been rubbed with dirt. In a series about bathing and cleanliness. It's silly.    Maybe Thermae Romae Novae picks up after this. I hear it has Kenjiro Tsuda yelling in Latin, so that's something.       Richard Eisenbeis  Rating:                It's funny, Thermae Romae is so mainstream here in Japan that despite never having read a page of the manga nor having seen the live-action film, I already knew the basic setup through cultural osmosis alone—which is why watching this threw me for a bit of a loop. What I was expecting was a time-traveling Roman being awed by some facet of Japanese hot spring culture over and over again. And while that may be what the series turns into, this first episode was most certainly not.    Rather, this episode gives us the backstory for our series' protagonist Lucius, showing why he became a bathhouse architect and where his philosophy on bathing came from. But more than that, this episode is about how blue-collar workers find importance and pride in their daily toil. For a mason, it's knowing that their work will record the past and inspire the future. For Lucius' father and grandfather, it's about creating a place where people can be purged of stress and be ready to face a new day. In other words, they may be cogs in Roman society, but they know that they are vital to its functioning.    It makes for a solid setup to the series, even if it's ultimately not representative of the rest of the show. It's just a shame that the animation doesn't really hold up. In wide shots there is a noticeable drop in detail and in scenes with any kind of quick movement, it looks choppy to say the least. And the live-action ending with the author of the manga is pretty much Japanese TV in a nutshell—i.e., a person traveling around Japan talking about how cool some aspect of Japanese culture (usually food) really is.    All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More          ⬈ ⬋ - +                            feature          74 comments       The Spring 2022 Preview Guide   Apr  4, 01:29 74 comments                 anime    The thrilling conclusion of Magia Record is live! The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Thermae Romae Novae   Apr  1st 2022                   How would you rate episode 1 of Thermae Romae Novae (ONA) ?                     Community score: 3.0              What is this?   In Hadrian Rome, Lucius was a Roman architect whose designs often got rejected by builders. To cheer him up a friend of his invited him to relax at a thermae (public bath). Inside the bath Lucius was accidentally trapped in an underwater hole by suction; when he finally managed to emerge on the surface he found himself in a very different bath: in 20th century Japan.    Thermae Romae Novae is based on Mari Yamazaki's manga and is currently streaming on Netflix.      How was the first episode?    James Beckett  Rating:                One of the things that comes with having major ADHD is learning how to manage constantly shifting hyperfixations, which is to say that I can totally understand how something like Thermae Romae Novae could come into existence. I've spent a frankly embarrassing amount of hours obsessing over kaiju movies, tokusatsu shows, Gunpla models, and The Muppets (and that's just the stuff I've gotten into over the last five years or so), so I'm not all surprised to learn that there exists at least one person in the world whose love for ancient history, architecture, and public bathhouses intersected with such ferocity that an entire multi-media franchise was born.    Here's my main issue with Thermae Romae Novae: While I'm certainly always down to dig into some history and culture lessons, I myself don't particularly care about architecture, and I've never even stepped foot inside of a public bathhouse. Our main character, Lucius, has precisely two personality traits: He freaking loves architecture, and his dream in life is to—and I quote—“Build bathhouses that make everyone smile!” Even when you include the series' novel time-travel angle (which doesn't really impact the first episode of the show at all), the core of Thermae Romae Novae's appeal lies in its unapologetic obsession with bathhouse cultures past and present.    What that means is that, outside of the very specific niche appeal of the bathhouses themselves, I'm not finding much else to latch onto with this story. The historical drama isn't well-written enough to hold up on its own, and there's not much humor to be found outside of that. In short, while the material here is perfectly fine for an educational documentary, I'm not sure it makes for the kind of anime that I want to sit down and watch on a regular basis.    Heck, the anime actually comes with live-action documentary segments that close out its episodes, and I find those much more compelling than the rest of the show that they're attached to. The segments that follow author Mari Yamazaki's quest to “rediscover Japanese bathhouse culture” are genuinely interesting and feature some lovely footage of real-world bathhouse settings, and the anime's relatively drab and uninspired visuals simply don't hold up in comparison. It doesn't help that, in all of the scenes set inside the thermae themselves (of which there are many), the show slaps this hideous and cheap looking steam filter on top of the screen.    I've heard that Thermae Romae has a sizeable fan-base, so it's quite possible that future episodes of the show would give me more of a reason to stick around and get invested in the bathhouse mania of it all. As it stands, though, I don't think Thermae Romae Novae is for me; at the very least, if I ever do come back to the show, I can easily imagine skipping all of the anime parts to get to the documentary bits. That's apparently where the real bathhouse action is at.        Caitlin Moore  Rating:               The manga of Thermae Romae is a critically-acclaimed award winner. The first anime adaptation was a low-budget short that developed a cult following for its quirky humor. The new series that just premiered on Netflix, Thermae Romae Novae, has a TV run's worth of full-length episodes, complete with attempts at pathos and backstory, and has the same director as the critically-panned Africa Salaryman. It is also boring.    For a series with a concept as weird as “Roman architect time travels through a portal in a bath for inspiration,” you really don't need to put a lot of effort into building up character motivation. Yet for some reason, they felt the need to give Lucius a reason to really love baths and a tragic childhood involving a dead father and bullies. Can't he just be a dude who loves soaking in hot water and designing new ways to do it? The first episode has no jokes and just feels long, drawn-out, and pointless.    Yet somehow, that's not the most baffling decision the anime staff made. You see, the people in togas and marble buildings with columns aren't enough to make us realize this shit all happened a long time ago. We couldn't possibly manage to figure that out on our own. The distant past was all sepia-toned, right? They didn't invent bright colors until the '50s! Everything up until then was muddy and dim. Unfortunately, the half-assed color design, along with the pen-and-ink style shading, makes it look like everything has been rubbed with dirt. In a series about bathing and cleanliness. It's silly.    Maybe Thermae Romae Novae picks up after this. I hear it has Kenjiro Tsuda yelling in Latin, so that's something.       Richard Eisenbeis  Rating:                It's funny, Thermae Romae is so mainstream here in Japan that despite never having read a page of the manga nor having seen the live-action film, I already knew the basic setup through cultural osmosis alone—which is why watching this threw me for a bit of a loop. What I was expecting was a time-traveling Roman being awed by some facet of Japanese hot spring culture over and over again. And while that may be what the series turns into, this first episode was most certainly not.    Rather, this episode gives us the backstory for our series' protagonist Lucius, showing why he became a bathhouse architect and where his philosophy on bathing came from. But more than that, this episode is about how blue-collar workers find importance and pride in their daily toil. For a mason, it's knowing that their work will record the past and inspire the future. For Lucius' father and grandfather, it's about creating a place where people can be purged of stress and be ready to face a new day. In other words, they may be cogs in Roman society, but they know that they are vital to its functioning.    It makes for a solid setup to the series, even if it's ultimately not representative of the rest of the show. It's just a shame that the animation doesn't really hold up. In wide shots there is a noticeable drop in detail and in scenes with any kind of quick movement, it looks choppy to say the least. And the live-action ending with the author of the manga is pretty much Japanese TV in a nutshell—i.e., a person traveling around Japan talking about how cool some aspect of Japanese culture (usually food) really is.    All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More          ⬈ ⬋ - +                            feature          74 comments       The Spring 2022 Preview Guide   Apr  4, 01:29 74 comments                 anime    The thrilling conclusion of Magia Record is live! Title: Thermae Romae Novae - The Spring 2022 Preview Guide - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.             The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Thermae Romae Novae   Apr  1st 2022                   How would you rate episode 1 of Thermae Romae Novae (ONA) ?                     Community score: 3.0              What is this?   In Hadrian Rome, Lucius was a Roman architect whose designs often got rejected by builders. To cheer him up a friend of his invited him to relax at a thermae (public bath). Inside the bath Lucius was accidentally trapped in an underwater hole by suction; when he finally managed to emerge on the surface he found himself in a very different bath: in 20th century Japan.    Thermae Romae Novae is based on Mari Yamazaki's manga and is currently streaming on Netflix.      How was the first episode?    James Beckett  Rating:                One of the things that comes with having major ADHD is learning how to manage constantly shifting hyperfixations, which is to say that I can totally understand how something like Thermae Romae Novae could come into existence. I've spent a frankly embarrassing amount of hours obsessing over kaiju movies, tokusatsu shows, Gunpla models, and The Muppets (and that's just the stuff I've gotten into over the last five years or so), so I'm not all surprised to learn that there exists at least one person in the world whose love for ancient history, architecture, and public bathhouses intersected with such ferocity that an entire multi-media franchise was born.    Here's my main issue with Thermae Romae Novae: While I'm certainly always down to dig into some history and culture lessons, I myself don't particularly care about architecture, and I've never even stepped foot inside of a public bathhouse. Our main character, Lucius, has precisely two personality traits: He freaking loves architecture, and his dream in life is to—and I quote—“Build bathhouses that make everyone smile!” Even when you include the series' novel time-travel angle (which doesn't really impact the first episode of the show at all), the core of Thermae Romae Novae's appeal lies in its unapologetic obsession with bathhouse cultures past and present.    What that means is that, outside of the very specific niche appeal of the bathhouses themselves, I'm not finding much else to latch onto with this story. The historical drama isn't well-written enough to hold up on its own, and there's not much humor to be found outside of that. In short, while the material here is perfectly fine for an educational documentary, I'm not sure it makes for the kind of anime that I want to sit down and watch on a regular basis.    Heck, the anime actually comes with live-action documentary segments that close out its episodes, and I find those much more compelling than the rest of the show that they're attached to. The segments that follow author Mari Yamazaki's quest to “rediscover Japanese bathhouse culture” are genuinely interesting and feature some lovely footage of real-world bathhouse settings, and the anime's relatively drab and uninspired visuals simply don't hold up in comparison. It doesn't help that, in all of the scenes set inside the thermae themselves (of which there are many), the show slaps this hideous and cheap looking steam filter on top of the screen.    I've heard that Thermae Romae has a sizeable fan-base, so it's quite possible that future episodes of the show would give me more of a reason to stick around and get invested in the bathhouse mania of it all. As it stands, though, I don't think Thermae Romae Novae is for me; at the very least, if I ever do come back to the show, I can easily imagine skipping all of the anime parts to get to the documentary bits. That's apparently where the real bathhouse action is at.        Caitlin Moore  Rating:               The manga of Thermae Romae is a critically-acclaimed award winner. The first anime adaptation was a low-budget short that developed a cult following for its quirky humor. The new series that just premiered on Netflix, Thermae Romae Novae, has a TV run's worth of full-length episodes, complete with attempts at pathos and backstory, and has the same director as the critically-panned Africa Salaryman. It is also boring.    For a series with a concept as weird as “Roman architect time travels through a portal in a bath for inspiration,” you really don't need to put a lot of effort into building up character motivation. Yet for some reason, they felt the need to give Lucius a reason to really love baths and a tragic childhood involving a dead father and bullies. Can't he just be a dude who loves soaking in hot water and designing new ways to do it? The first episode has no jokes and just feels long, drawn-out, and pointless.    Yet somehow, that's not the most baffling decision the anime staff made. You see, the people in togas and marble buildings with columns aren't enough to make us realize this shit all happened a long time ago. We couldn't possibly manage to figure that out on our own. The distant past was all sepia-toned, right? They didn't invent bright colors until the '50s! Everything up until then was muddy and dim. Unfortunately, the half-assed color design, along with the pen-and-ink style shading, makes it look like everything has been rubbed with dirt. In a series about bathing and cleanliness. It's silly.    Maybe Thermae Romae Novae picks up after this. I hear it has Kenjiro Tsuda yelling in Latin, so that's something.       Richard Eisenbeis  Rating:                It's funny, Thermae Romae is so mainstream here in Japan that despite never having read a page of the manga nor having seen the live-action film, I already knew the basic setup through cultural osmosis alone—which is why watching this threw me for a bit of a loop. What I was expecting was a time-traveling Roman being awed by some facet of Japanese hot spring culture over and over again. And while that may be what the series turns into, this first episode was most certainly not.    Rather, this episode gives us the backstory for our series' protagonist Lucius, showing why he became a bathhouse architect and where his philosophy on bathing came from. But more than that, this episode is about how blue-collar workers find importance and pride in their daily toil. For a mason, it's knowing that their work will record the past and inspire the future. For Lucius' father and grandfather, it's about creating a place where people can be purged of stress and be ready to face a new day. In other words, they may be cogs in Roman society, but they know that they are vital to its functioning.    It makes for a solid setup to the series, even if it's ultimately not representative of the rest of the show. It's just a shame that the animation doesn't really hold up. In wide shots there is a noticeable drop in detail and in scenes with any kind of quick movement, it looks choppy to say the least. And the live-action ending with the author of the manga is pretty much Japanese TV in a nutshell—i.e., a person traveling around Japan talking about how cool some aspect of Japanese culture (usually food) really is.    All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More

All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives

Title: Thermae Romae Novae - The Spring 2022 Preview Guide - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: How would you rate episode 1 of Thermae Romae Novae (ONA) ?                     Community score: 3.0              What is this?   In Hadrian Rome, Lucius was a Roman architect whose designs often got rejected by builders. To cheer him up a friend of his invited him to relax at a thermae (public bath). Inside the bath Lucius was accidentally trapped in an underwater hole by suction; when he finally managed to emerge on the surface he found himself in a very different bath: in 20th century Japan.    Thermae Romae Novae is based on Mari Yamazaki's manga and is currently streaming on Netflix.      How was the first episode?    James Beckett  Rating:                One of the things that comes with having major ADHD is learning how to manage constantly shifting hyperfixations, which is to say that I can totally understand how something like Thermae Romae Novae could come into existence. I've spent a frankly embarrassing amount of hours obsessing over kaiju movies, tokusatsu shows, Gunpla models, and The Muppets (and that's just the stuff I've gotten into over the last five years or so), so I'm not all surprised to learn that there exists at least one person in the world whose love for ancient history, architecture, and public bathhouses intersected with such ferocity that an entire multi-media franchise was born.    Here's my main issue with Thermae Romae Novae: While I'm certainly always down to dig into some history and culture lessons, I myself don't particularly care about architecture, and I've never even stepped foot inside of a public bathhouse. Our main character, Lucius, has precisely two personality traits: He freaking loves architecture, and his dream in life is to—and I quote—“Build bathhouses that make everyone smile!” Even when you include the series' novel time-travel angle (which doesn't really impact the first episode of the show at all), the core of Thermae Romae Novae's appeal lies in its unapologetic obsession with bathhouse cultures past and present.    What that means is that, outside of the very specific niche appeal of the bathhouses themselves, I'm not finding much else to latch onto with this story. The historical drama isn't well-written enough to hold up on its own, and there's not much humor to be found outside of that. In short, while the material here is perfectly fine for an educational documentary, I'm not sure it makes for the kind of anime that I want to sit down and watch on a regular basis.    Heck, the anime actually comes with live-action documentary segments that close out its episodes, and I find those much more compelling than the rest of the show that they're attached to. The segments that follow author Mari Yamazaki's quest to “rediscover Japanese bathhouse culture” are genuinely interesting and feature some lovely footage of real-world bathhouse settings, and the anime's relatively drab and uninspired visuals simply don't hold up in comparison. It doesn't help that, in all of the scenes set inside the thermae themselves (of which there are many), the show slaps this hideous and cheap looking steam filter on top of the screen.    I've heard that Thermae Romae has a sizeable fan-base, so it's quite possible that future episodes of the show would give me more of a reason to stick around and get invested in the bathhouse mania of it all. As it stands, though, I don't think Thermae Romae Novae is for me; at the very least, if I ever do come back to the show, I can easily imagine skipping all of the anime parts to get to the documentary bits. That's apparently where the real bathhouse action is at.        Caitlin Moore  Rating:               The manga of Thermae Romae is a critically-acclaimed award winner. The first anime adaptation was a low-budget short that developed a cult following for its quirky humor. The new series that just premiered on Netflix, Thermae Romae Novae, has a TV run's worth of full-length episodes, complete with attempts at pathos and backstory, and has the same director as the critically-panned Africa Salaryman. It is also boring.    For a series with a concept as weird as “Roman architect time travels through a portal in a bath for inspiration,” you really don't need to put a lot of effort into building up character motivation. Yet for some reason, they felt the need to give Lucius a reason to really love baths and a tragic childhood involving a dead father and bullies. Can't he just be a dude who loves soaking in hot water and designing new ways to do it? The first episode has no jokes and just feels long, drawn-out, and pointless.    Yet somehow, that's not the most baffling decision the anime staff made. You see, the people in togas and marble buildings with columns aren't enough to make us realize this shit all happened a long time ago. We couldn't possibly manage to figure that out on our own. The distant past was all sepia-toned, right? They didn't invent bright colors until the '50s! Everything up until then was muddy and dim. Unfortunately, the half-assed color design, along with the pen-and-ink style shading, makes it look like everything has been rubbed with dirt. In a series about bathing and cleanliness. It's silly.    Maybe Thermae Romae Novae picks up after this. I hear it has Kenjiro Tsuda yelling in Latin, so that's something.       Richard Eisenbeis  Rating:                It's funny, Thermae Romae is so mainstream here in Japan that despite never having read a page of the manga nor having seen the live-action film, I already knew the basic setup through cultural osmosis alone—which is why watching this threw me for a bit of a loop. What I was expecting was a time-traveling Roman being awed by some facet of Japanese hot spring culture over and over again. And while that may be what the series turns into, this first episode was most certainly not.    Rather, this episode gives us the backstory for our series' protagonist Lucius, showing why he became a bathhouse architect and where his philosophy on bathing came from. But more than that, this episode is about how blue-collar workers find importance and pride in their daily toil. For a mason, it's knowing that their work will record the past and inspire the future. For Lucius' father and grandfather, it's about creating a place where people can be purged of stress and be ready to face a new day. In other words, they may be cogs in Roman society, but they know that they are vital to its functioning.    It makes for a solid setup to the series, even if it's ultimately not representative of the rest of the show. It's just a shame that the animation doesn't really hold up. In wide shots there is a noticeable drop in detail and in scenes with any kind of quick movement, it looks choppy to say the least. And the live-action ending with the author of the manga is pretty much Japanese TV in a nutshell—i.e., a person traveling around Japan talking about how cool some aspect of Japanese culture (usually food) really is.    All in all, I don't know if it's my cup of tea but it certainly wasn't bad.     discuss this in the forum (74 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                         this article has been modified since it was originally posted;      see change history    back to The Spring 2022 Preview Guide Season Preview Guide homepage / archives

That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories Collaboration Event with PAC-MAN Announcement   Apr  2nd 2022         New-York, New-York, March 31, 2021 - Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc.'s new smartphone game for the App Store and Google Play, That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories, is teaming up for a collaboration event with PAC-MAN called "That Time I Found PAC-MAN in Another World".  ------------------------------------   The game will get a PAC-MAN-style makeover!    For a limited time, you'll see special animation and illustrations when you log in!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Rimuru turns into PAC-MAN in-game!    Tap Rimuru on the Home screen to display a button that will transform him into PAC-MAN! Roam the streets of Tempest as PAC-MAN!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   An exclusive PAC-MAN-related story!    The event is written by Fuse, author of the original novels, and will be fully voiced! Hidden away in Ramiris's Treasure Vault is an old-fashioned PAC-MAN arcade cabinet. Series creator Fuse treats us to an exclusive story about Rimuru, Ramiris, and the Academy kids playing the Earth arcade classic!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Play a PAC-MAN mini-game!    Clearing the event Story quests will unlock blueprints for an arcade facility! You'll be able to build your very own arcade in Tempest!  Once your arcade is complete, it will grant you access to a special website (the game will launch a web browser) where you can play a special Slime Isekai-themed PAC-MAN mini-game!  *System Requirements: Google Chrome latest version, Safari latest version, iPhone Safari latest version, Android Chrome latest version. OS: iPhone: iOS 13.4 to 15.3, Android: ver8.0 - . iOS 15.4 is currently deprecated.  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Face the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!    Fight the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!  And prepare yourself for ghost-hunting missions!  If all Slime IM players can defeat a combined total of One million ghosts, all Chancellors will get rewards!  We plan to keep the global ghost-chomping total updated on our official Facebook as well as in-game.  ■Rewards Everyone will get the rewards below: ・Total 100,000: Recruit Ticket x1 ・Total 250,000: Recruit Ticket x2 ・Total 500,000: Recruit Ticket x3 ・Total 750,000: Recruit Ticket x4 ・Total 1,000,000: The PAC-MAN event illustration displayed at login (The illustration will be added to your Gallery.)  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Reward distribution scheduled to begin 4/12 (Tue) 02:00 UTC  7. Get up to 200 Magicrystals between the login bonus and event clear bonuses!  Get 100 Magicrystals from the PAC-MAN event login bonus! But that's not all! Get up to 100 more Magicrystals by clearing the Story quests and Predator Battles!  [Rewards for Story Quests & Predator Battles] ・Story: Ramiris's Treasure Vault　      Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Clyde    Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Inky       Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Blinky   Magicrystal x25  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.  Don't miss this limited-time PAC-MAN collaboration event!  ------------------------------------   Title: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories  Game Genre: Nation Building 3D Battle RPG  Retail Price: Free to play with some in-app purchases  Available for: App Store, Google Play  Official Website URL: https://ten-sura-m.bn-ent.net/en/   App Store   Google Play    © Taiki Kawakami, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura” Project © Shiba, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura Diary” Project ©Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc. That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories Collaboration Event with PAC-MAN Announcement   Apr  2nd 2022         New-York, New-York, March 31, 2021 - Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc.'s new smartphone game for the App Store and Google Play, That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories, is teaming up for a collaboration event with PAC-MAN called "That Time I Found PAC-MAN in Another World".  ------------------------------------   The game will get a PAC-MAN-style makeover!    For a limited time, you'll see special animation and illustrations when you log in!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Rimuru turns into PAC-MAN in-game!    Tap Rimuru on the Home screen to display a button that will transform him into PAC-MAN! Roam the streets of Tempest as PAC-MAN!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   An exclusive PAC-MAN-related story!    The event is written by Fuse, author of the original novels, and will be fully voiced! Hidden away in Ramiris's Treasure Vault is an old-fashioned PAC-MAN arcade cabinet. Series creator Fuse treats us to an exclusive story about Rimuru, Ramiris, and the Academy kids playing the Earth arcade classic!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Play a PAC-MAN mini-game!    Clearing the event Story quests will unlock blueprints for an arcade facility! You'll be able to build your very own arcade in Tempest!  Once your arcade is complete, it will grant you access to a special website (the game will launch a web browser) where you can play a special Slime Isekai-themed PAC-MAN mini-game!  *System Requirements: Google Chrome latest version, Safari latest version, iPhone Safari latest version, Android Chrome latest version. OS: iPhone: iOS 13.4 to 15.3, Android: ver8.0 - . iOS 15.4 is currently deprecated.  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Face the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!    Fight the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!  And prepare yourself for ghost-hunting missions!  If all Slime IM players can defeat a combined total of One million ghosts, all Chancellors will get rewards!  We plan to keep the global ghost-chomping total updated on our official Facebook as well as in-game.  ■Rewards Everyone will get the rewards below: ・Total 100,000: Recruit Ticket x1 ・Total 250,000: Recruit Ticket x2 ・Total 500,000: Recruit Ticket x3 ・Total 750,000: Recruit Ticket x4 ・Total 1,000,000: The PAC-MAN event illustration displayed at login (The illustration will be added to your Gallery.)  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Reward distribution scheduled to begin 4/12 (Tue) 02:00 UTC  7. Get up to 200 Magicrystals between the login bonus and event clear bonuses!  Get 100 Magicrystals from the PAC-MAN event login bonus! But that's not all! Get up to 100 more Magicrystals by clearing the Story quests and Predator Battles!  [Rewards for Story Quests & Predator Battles] ・Story: Ramiris's Treasure Vault　      Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Clyde    Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Inky       Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Blinky   Magicrystal x25  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.  Don't miss this limited-time PAC-MAN collaboration event!  ------------------------------------   Title: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories  Game Genre: Nation Building 3D Battle RPG  Retail Price: Free to play with some in-app purchases  Available for: App Store, Google Play  Official Website URL: https://ten-sura-m.bn-ent.net/en/   App Store   Google Play    © Taiki Kawakami, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura” Project © Shiba, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura Diary” Project ©Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc. That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories Collaboration Event with PAC-MAN Announcement   Apr  2nd 2022         New-York, New-York, March 31, 2021 - Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc.'s new smartphone game for the App Store and Google Play, That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories, is teaming up for a collaboration event with PAC-MAN called "That Time I Found PAC-MAN in Another World".  ------------------------------------   The game will get a PAC-MAN-style makeover!    For a limited time, you'll see special animation and illustrations when you log in!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Rimuru turns into PAC-MAN in-game!    Tap Rimuru on the Home screen to display a button that will transform him into PAC-MAN! Roam the streets of Tempest as PAC-MAN!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   An exclusive PAC-MAN-related story!    The event is written by Fuse, author of the original novels, and will be fully voiced! Hidden away in Ramiris's Treasure Vault is an old-fashioned PAC-MAN arcade cabinet. Series creator Fuse treats us to an exclusive story about Rimuru, Ramiris, and the Academy kids playing the Earth arcade classic!  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Play a PAC-MAN mini-game!    Clearing the event Story quests will unlock blueprints for an arcade facility! You'll be able to build your very own arcade in Tempest!  Once your arcade is complete, it will grant you access to a special website (the game will launch a web browser) where you can play a special Slime Isekai-themed PAC-MAN mini-game!  *System Requirements: Google Chrome latest version, Safari latest version, iPhone Safari latest version, Android Chrome latest version. OS: iPhone: iOS 13.4 to 15.3, Android: ver8.0 - . iOS 15.4 is currently deprecated.  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.   Face the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!    Fight the PAC-MAN ghosts in Predator Battles!  And prepare yourself for ghost-hunting missions!  If all Slime IM players can defeat a combined total of One million ghosts, all Chancellors will get rewards!  We plan to keep the global ghost-chomping total updated on our official Facebook as well as in-game.  ■Rewards Everyone will get the rewards below: ・Total 100,000: Recruit Ticket x1 ・Total 250,000: Recruit Ticket x2 ・Total 500,000: Recruit Ticket x3 ・Total 750,000: Recruit Ticket x4 ・Total 1,000,000: The PAC-MAN event illustration displayed at login (The illustration will be added to your Gallery.)  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Reward distribution scheduled to begin 4/12 (Tue) 02:00 UTC  7. Get up to 200 Magicrystals between the login bonus and event clear bonuses!  Get 100 Magicrystals from the PAC-MAN event login bonus! But that's not all! Get up to 100 more Magicrystals by clearing the Story quests and Predator Battles!  [Rewards for Story Quests & Predator Battles] ・Story: Ramiris's Treasure Vault　      Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Clyde    Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Inky       Magicrystal x25 ・Predator Battle: Press Start: Blinky   Magicrystal x25  *Event period: 3/31 (Thu) 15:00 – 4/8 (Fri) 5:59 UTC  *Campaign period and content subject to change without notice. *Please check the app for details.  Don't miss this limited-time PAC-MAN collaboration event!  ------------------------------------   Title: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: ISEKAI Memories  Game Genre: Nation Building 3D Battle RPG  Retail Price: Free to play with some in-app purchases  Available for: App Store, Google Play  Official Website URL: https://ten-sura-m.bn-ent.net/en/   App Store   Google Play    © Taiki Kawakami, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura” Project © Shiba, Fuse, KODANSHA/“Ten-Sura Diary” Project ©Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc.
